Am I reinventing the wheel here? Mathematically the set-up is: V is a vector space over a field K (or a module over a ring) and K -> K' is a morphism of fields, and then quadratic or bilinear forms on VVV should push forward to quadratic or bilinear forms on V⊗KK′V\otimes_K K'V⊗K​K′ (at least if 2 is invertible, in the quadratic form case).

import Mathlib

-- I want to do base change for quadratic forms.
-- How much of the below is re-inventing the wheel?

-- M and N are R-modules and A is an R-algebra and T is an A-module
variables (R A M N T : Type) [CommRing R] [CommRing A] [Algebra R A]
  [AddCommGroup M] [AddCommGroup N] [Module R M] [Module R N]
  [AddCommGroup T] [Module A T]
  -- and I want to regard T as an R-module too, in the obvious way
  [Module R T] [IsScalarTower R A T]

open TensorProduct -- for notation

def LinearMap.baseChangeLeft (f : M →ₗ[R] T) : A ⊗[R] M →ₗ[A] T where
  toFun := TensorProduct.lift ({
    toFun := fun a ↦ a • f
    map_add' := sorry
    map_smul' := sorry
  } : A →ₗ[R] M →ₗ[R] T)
  map_add' := sorry
  map_smul' := sorry

def algebraMap' : R →ₗ[R] A where
  toFun := algebraMap R A
  map_add' := sorry
  map_smul' := sorry

def TensorProduct.rid' : A ⊗[R] R ≃ₗ[A] A where
  toLinearMap := LinearMap.baseChangeLeft R A R A (algebraMap' R A)
  invFun := fun a ↦ a ⊗ₜ 1
  left_inv := sorry
  right_inv := sorry

def BilinForm.baseChange (F : BilinForm R M) : BilinForm A (A ⊗[R] M) := by
  let L := BilinForm.toLinHom R F
  let L' := L.baseChange A
  refine LinearMap.toBilin ?_
  refine LinearMap.comp ?_ L'
  apply LinearMap.baseChangeLeft
  refine LinearMap.comp ?_ (LinearMap.baseChangeHom R A _ _)
  apply LinearMap.restrictScalars R (S := A)
  refine LinearMap.llcomp A _ _ _ (?_ : A ⊗[R] R →ₗ[A] A)
  exact (TensorProduct.rid' R A).toLinearMap

def QuadraticForm.baseChange [Invertible (2 : R)] (F : QuadraticForm R M) : QuadraticForm A (A ⊗[R] M) := by
  let B : BilinForm R M := associatedHom R F
  let B' : BilinForm A (A ⊗[R] M) := B.baseChange R A M
  exact B'.toQuadraticForm

There are multiple definitions of quadratic forms (especially in characteristic two), but the classical one, when written in coordinates, exactly amounts to homogeneous polynomial maps of degree two. And you know how to base change them.

You may ask: what if I have no coordinates, or quadratic forms from one module to another one, etc.

Given a commutative ring kkk and kkk-modules M,NM,NM,N, there is a notion of polynomial map fff from MMM to NNN: this is the datum of maps fR ⁣:M⊗kR→N⊗kRf_R\colon M\otimes_k R\to N\otimes_k RfR​:M⊗k​R→N⊗k​R for any kkk-algebra RRR subject to a naturality condition. You can then prove that such a family of maps is naturally a polynomial in the sense that for every family (m1,m2,… )(m_1,m_2,\dots)(m1​,m2​,…) of elements of MMM, there is a polynomial cmc_mcm​ in indeterminates T1,T2,…T_1,T_2,\dotsT1​,T2​,… (valued in NNN) such that fR(a1m1+a2m2+… )=cm(a1,a2,… )f_R (a_1m_1+a_2m_2+\dots) = c_m(a_1,a_2,\dots)fR​(a1​m1​+a2​m2​+…)=cm​(a1​,a2​,…) for all families (a1,a2,… )(a_1,a_2,\dots)(a1​,a2​,…) in RRR. Homogeneous components give rise to multilinear maps, there are polarization identities, etc.

Polynomial maps form a graded kkk-module and there is a universal one (in each degree nnn): the… divided power algebra DPn(M)\mathrm{DP}_n(M)DPn​(M) in the sense that that there is homogeneous polynomial map M→DPn(M)M\to \mathrm{DP}_n(M)M→DPn​(M) — given by m↦m(n) m\mapsto m^{(n)} m↦m(n), the n n n-th divided power of m m m — so that any polynomial map M→N M\to N M→N which is homogeneous of degree nnn is of the form m↦ϕ(m(n)) m\mapsto \phi(m^ { (n) } ) m↦ϕ(m(n)) for a unique linear map DPn(M)→N\mathrm{DP}_n(M)\to NDPn​(M)→N.

import Mathlib

variable (R A M N T : Type) [CommRing R] [CommRing A] [Algebra R A]
  [AddCommGroup M] [AddCommGroup N] [Module R M] [Module R N]
  [AddCommGroup T] [Module A T] [Module R T] [IsScalarTower R A T]

open TensorProduct

def LinearMap.baseChangeLeft (f : M →ₗ[R] T) : A ⊗[R] M →ₗ[A] T where
  toFun := TensorProduct.lift ({
    toFun := fun a ↦ a • f
    map_add' := fun x y => add_smul x y f
    map_smul' := by
      intro r x
      simp only [smul_assoc, RingHom.id_apply]
  } : A →ₗ[R] M →ₗ[R] T)
  map_add' := map_add _
  map_smul' := by
    intro a x
    simp only [RingHom.id_apply]
    refine TensorProduct.induction_on x ?_ ?_ ?_
    · simp
    · intros b m
      simp [mul_smul a b (f m), show a • b ⊗ₜ[R] m = (a * b) ⊗ₜ[R] m from rfl]
    · intros x y hx hy
      simp [hx, hy]

def algebraMap' : R →ₗ[R] A where
  toFun := algebraMap R A
  map_add' := by simp
  map_smul' := by
    intros r s
    simp [Algebra.smul_def r ((algebraMap R A) s)]

def TensorProduct.rid' : A ⊗[R] R ≃ₗ[A] A where
  toLinearMap := LinearMap.baseChangeLeft R A R A (algebraMap' R A)
  invFun := fun a ↦ a ⊗ₜ 1
  left_inv := by
    intro x
    refine TensorProduct.induction_on x ?_ ?_ ?_
    · simp [LinearMap.baseChangeLeft, algebraMap']
    · intros a r
      simp [LinearMap.baseChangeLeft, algebraMap']
      rw [mul_comm]
      nth_rewrite 2 [show r = r • (1 : R) by simp]
      rw [← smul_tmul, _root_.Algebra.smul_def]
    · intros x y hx hy
      rw [AddHom.map_add']
      simp_all
      rw [add_tmul, hx, hy]
  right_inv := by
    intro a
    simp [LinearMap.baseChangeLeft, algebraMap']

This proof indeed goes through:

import Mathlib

open scoped TensorProduct

/-- If a base change exists for a quadratic form, it is unique -/
theorem QuadraticForm.baseChange_unique {R A M : Type*}
    [CommRing R] [CommRing A] [AddCommGroup M] [Algebra R A] [Module R M]
    (Q : QuadraticForm R M) (Q₁ Q₂ : QuadraticForm A (A ⊗[R] M))
    (h₁ : ∀ a m, Q₁ (a ⊗ₜ m) = a^2 * algebraMap _ _ (Q m))
    (h₂ : ∀ a m, Q₂ (a ⊗ₜ m) = a^2 * algebraMap _ _ (Q m)) :
    Q₁ = Q₂ := by
  ext x
  have : Q₁.polarBilin = Q₂.polarBilin := by
    ext
    dsimp
    simp [h₁, h₂, polar, ← TensorProduct.tmul_add]
  induction x using TensorProduct.induction_on with
  | tmul => simp [h₁, h₂]
  | zero => simp
  | @add x y hx hy =>
    have := congr($this x y)
    dsimp [polar] at this
    linear_combination this + hx + hy
